author: potuz
content: Hi guys/gals I figured it may faster to ask here, I haven't looked into implementations of `hash_tree_root` besides mine and the python reference one by Vitalik. I'm wondering if there's one (or perhaps all) that breaks the leaves into subsets and hashes in parallel. If so, what's the threshold to switch from a single thread implementation to a multi threaded one?

author: potuz
content: I mean to hash a Merkle tree

author: peter.davies
content: My understanding is that trie operations are in practice in entirely disk seek limited. Hence why everyone runs eth clients on SSDs.

author: peter.davies
content: Databases really don't like people want to look up loads of effectively random keys.

author: potuz
content: No no, I'm interested in eth2

author: potuz
content: The largest chunk that needs to be hashed is the state

author: potuz
content: And it's small

author: potuz
content: Just a few megabytes

author: potuz
content: What I don't know is if the implementations out there do this in parallel or is single threaded

author: potuz
content: There's a huge overhead in forking that I'm not sure it's worth it (not if it's worth my time trying to benchmark it)

author: danielr0508
content: Chasing POAP credentials here. Would you add me to the apprenticeship role please?

author: ralexstokes
content: i've only seen single-threaded impls but i don't claim to have looked at most of them or even that closely at the ones that exist

author: ralexstokes
content: i'm sure we could explore parallel hashing for the hash tree construction but there are certainly other bottlenecks in eth2 clients today that would take priority

author: ralexstokes
content: the bigger gain as i understand it is to only compute the minimum number of hashes to get a new root for each edit to an ssz object

author: ralexstokes
content: so caching all of the hashes in your data representation and then on each edit to the data only changes the log(n) hashes up to the root

author: ralexstokes
content:
i'm actually in the middle of (yet another) ssz impl here: https://github.com/ralexstokes/ssz

unless i missed something w/ serialization, that should all be done and the next thing to do will be implementing Merkleization, so if you'd want to hop on, let's chat

author: ralexstokes
content: ultimately i'm looking to be able to make nice multiproofs for a light client prototype i'd like to work on next (hopefully just as Altair is going live üôÇ )

author: potuz
content: Thanks, <@203220829473996800> has been putting me up to date with the caching mechanisms of clients that make it so parallelization might be not much gain

author: ralexstokes
content: cool cool

author: potuz
content: Thinking more about my objective I start to

author: potuz
content: Suspect that actually not hashing at all

author: potuz
content: And not checking signatures might be a winning strategy

author: ralexstokes
content: you just want a faster state transition?

author: potuz
content: Oh thanks I'll look at this. I just finished implementing serialization on c++ but didn't take cashing into account so it may have been in vain

author: ralexstokes
content: not in vain if you feel like you learned something imo

author: ralexstokes
content: that repo only has serialization code, the Merkle code will be forthcoming (tm)

author: potuz
content: I want to measure economic incentive into not doing anything that is not enforced by the protocol, like not keeping blocks

author: ralexstokes
content: ah right i recall -- there is a lot you could skip at the risk of being a serious "leech" on the network

author: ralexstokes
content: then trying to distill economic incentives to do this is a tricky one -- that seems to me like you'd want to start w/ just analyzing the spec, not so much building/modifying a client

author: potuz
content: Yeah but I think I got already the part of looking where to cheat

author: potuz
content: Now I want to implement it

author: potuz
content: I think probably the biggest winner will be not checking execution payload

author: potuz
content: And attesting as valid

author: potuz
content: Haven't looked into sharding yet

author: potuz
content: I would actually want to be a leech. And the best outcome that I would hope is that leeching does not improve performance by much

author: potuz
content: But I want to quantify this

author: ralexstokes
content: have you looked at the proof-of-custody scheme?

author: ralexstokes
content: not sure if there is anything written down but i also know <@!555483069038198827> has been working on an execution proof-of-custody

author: ralexstokes
content: and if you are blindly attesting to beacon blocks/shards you will get slashed sooner or later

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah would be awesome to see any data you can gather on this question but i expect you'd do well as you could just run very cheap validators so end up w/ more staking profit

author: ralexstokes
content: if you find any big gaps we will turn around and try to patch in the spec üôÇ

author: potuz
content: That's not the case now nor right after the merge, you mean after sharding right?

author: potuz
content: Yeah in that case I agree that not checking signatures can get you slashed

author: ralexstokes
content: whenever we add the proof-of-custody game

author: potuz
content: In any case what I am hoping to find is what you mention, a slight increase in performance. One immediate is that only keeping finalized blocks saves a bit on disk, but that's really marginal cause you can run thousands of keys on one dbase.

author: ralexstokes
content: there is a version of sharding that is "honest majority" where there is no proof-of-custody

author: ralexstokes
content: but likely will deploy some proof-of-custody soon after the bare data shards

author: ralexstokes
content: it would be interesting to see mainnet numbers re: peer scoring

author: ralexstokes
content: in an ideal world, each clients p2p layer would detect that you don't have blocks to share and they would down score you over time

author: potuz
content: Yeah I've been following your conversations with Mikhail on the <#595701195843174434> Chanel... I suppose after sharding there's an entirely new world for"cheating" in this sense.

author: potuz
content: The whole idea came from an argument that people from Nimbus had with guys from Teku regarding the back filling of blocks of a client that synced from a state

author: potuz
content: I think it's almost unenforceable because there may never be the need to check for this

author: potuz
content: So implementing a proof of custody for old blocks is not priority

author: potuz
content: This I suppose will be a reality among main clients eventually (a flag to not hold old data) if they don't have it already

author: potuz
content: As for being kicked out, haven't checked yet, but seems to be simple to spoof different enrs and try to reconnect

author: ralexstokes
content: but then you would lose any reputation you had w/ that particular peer id

author: ralexstokes
content: and clients can generally try to mitigate many connections from the same IP

author: potuz
content: Missed this message ^ I don't know about other clients but prysm only downscores now on bad data

author: ralexstokes
content: either way, there is a broad space for hardening the p2p layer

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah i'd expect clients to differentiate into e.g. just "consensus clients" and such clients only have data needed for consensus

author: ralexstokes
content: which kind of suggests you only need data for the current weak subjectivity period and can prune data that falls outside of it

author: ralexstokes
content: an even more aggressive client would just drop stuff after finality, w/ the caveats around various custody guarantees they may be responsible for

author: potuz
content: But on the enr you can even hide the public IP (on the advertised part of the string) I think any way no client is analyzing IP numbers, just peer id

author: ralexstokes
content: yeah but should be straightforward to do so

author: ralexstokes
content: and if it becomes relevant, clients will do so

author: potuz
content: Danny Ryan told me that the portal network would mitigate a bit the p2p issues with leeches (at least it was my reading of his message  üòÇ )

author: ralexstokes
content: definitely want the portal network and stuff like it to handle the case for "data outside of consensus" -- it is still valuable and ppl will want it

author: pipermerriam
content:
One of the things that I think may play out with Portal Network vs DevP2p-eth1/libp2p-eth2 networks is the division of consensus critical vs not.  There seems to be some benefit in trying to isolate the consensus critical stuff (block propogation for eth1) from the non consensus critical stuff (sync, history, maybe even tx gossip).  The security requirements for these two categories are very different so having them bundled puts too much overhead on the non-critical stuff and also exposes the critical functionality to problems that arise from the non-critical stuff.

In a world where the two are separate, issues with state sync, history sync might prevent new clients from joining the network but the network would continue onwards.  In the same vein issues with tx gossip could cause congestion or UX issues, but the network would continue onwards.  I'd love to see the DevP2P `eth` protocol get slimmed all the way down to only the propogation of new blocks, and to move all of the other functionality into different non-critical sub protocols.

I think the other thing that this does is allow for more rapid development and experimentation in these non-critical sub protocols, something that has and continues to be difficult in the current protocol.

author: potuz

author: potuz
content: I'll continue abusing this channel but since I'm very new here and finding historical literature on Ethereum is impossible I feel entitled: is the order of members on the `BeaconState` structure optimized for the problem of minimizing the number of hashes that one needs to make given a hash for a state and a block to apply state transition to it? Given the merkleization algorithm my intuition would have been to collect the fields that change the most together. And mostly to the boundaries of the container. This doesn't seem to be the case. Same question applies for serialization. It does seem to me that the ordering of the members actually has an impact. cc <@203220829473996800> who surely thought about this. And apologies in advance for asking something that must have been discussed here (couldn't find it here nor on ethresear.ch)

author: potuz
content: Things like for example putting the historical stuff early and ordering some in reverse order so that the changing parts stay together seems obvious
